articles.headline: ‘Big Red Flag’: Automakers’ Trade Secrets Exposed in Data Leak
articles.snippet: A small contractor’s unguarded server accidentally revealed a trove of corporate documents from Tesla, Toyota, Volkswagen and other manufacturers.
articles.abstract: A small contractor’s unguarded server accidentally revealed a trove of corporate documents from Tesla, Toyota, Volkswagen and other manufacturers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Automakers like Tesla, Toyota and Volkswagen go to great lengths to keep their technical information confidential. Details about assembly line machinery and proprietary robotics are among the industry’s most closely guarded trade secrets.

articles.headline: California Wants to Reinvent the Power Grid. So What Could Go Wrong?
articles.snippet: Two decades ago, a new approach to power delivery led to blackouts. Now the state is considering another energy makeover: a regional electric grid.
articles.abstract: Two decades ago, a new approach to power delivery led to blackouts. Now the state is considering another energy makeover: a regional electric grid.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Two decades ago, when California deregulated the delivery of electric power, lawmakers, regulators and even some environmentalists hailed the decision as a way to lower consumers’ bills.

articles.headline: Missouri Duck Boat Accident Kills 17, Including 9 From Same Family
articles.snippet: The tourist boat, carrying 31 people, sank in a storm that hit with shocking ferocity, raising new concerns about the safety of duck boats.
articles.abstract: The tourist boat, carrying 31 people, sank in a storm that hit with shocking ferocity, raising new concerns about the safety of duck boats.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRANSON, Mo. — The image from Table Rock Lake that onlookers say they will never forget is the heads, one after another, bobbing in the wild, darkened water.
articles.byline: By John Eligon, Timothy Williams, Mitch Smith and Karen Zraick

articles.headline: Shonda Rhimes Describes Her Grand Netflix Ambitions
articles.snippet: The star producer reveals the eight shows she plans to make for the streaming service, which wooed her away from ABC with a nine-figure deal.
articles.abstract: The star producer reveals the eight shows she plans to make for the streaming service, which wooed her away from ABC with a nine-figure deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Shonda Rhimes achieved almost everything a television producer could hope for during her long run at ABC. She made herself into not only one of the most prolific writer-producers in the business, but also a mogul, as the founder and head of the Shondaland production company. ABC filled its entire Thursday night lineup with shows created or produced by her — a body of work that includes “Grey’s Anatomy,” “Scandal” and “How to Get Away With Murder” — but Ms. Rhimes was restless.

articles.headline: Year After White Nationalist Rally, Charlottesville Is in Tug of War Over Its Soul
articles.snippet: Nearly a year after the rally, the city’s first black female mayor has vowed to address centuries of racial and economic disparities.
articles.abstract: Nearly a year after the rally, the city’s first black female mayor has vowed to address centuries of racial and economic disparities.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — In the days following the deadly white nationalist rally in Charlottesville last summer, angry residents took over a City Council meeting, screaming and weeping into the microphone. They blamed leaders for failing to stop hordes with guns, swastikas and Confederate flags from descending on the city.

articles.headline: There Is a Revolution on the Left. Democrats Are Bracing.
articles.snippet: After victories by progressive candidates in New York, Pennsylvania, Michigan and Maryland, young liberals are trying to remake the party into a ferocious opposition force.
articles.abstract: After victories by progressive candidates in New York, Pennsylvania, Michigan and Maryland, young liberals are trying to remake the party into a ferocious opposition force.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — For Rachel Conner, the 2018 election season has been a moment of revelation.

articles.headline: Brazil’s Military Strides Into Politics, by the Ballot or by Force
articles.snippet: Scores of former officers are running for office. And if the ballot box doesn’t work, some former officials warn of a possible military coup.
articles.abstract: Scores of former officers are running for office. And if the ballot box doesn’t work, some former officials warn of a possible military coup.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Members of Brazil’s armed forces, who have largely stayed out of political life since the end of the military dictatorship 30 years ago, are making their biggest incursion into politics in decades, with some even warning of a military intervention.
articles.byline: By Ernesto Londoño and Manuela Andreoni

articles.headline: Tabloid Company, Aiding Trump Campaign, May Have Crossed Line Into Politics
articles.snippet: Federal authorities believe that American Media Inc. acted more as a political supporter than as a news organization as it helped Michael D. Cohen suppress embarrassing coverage.
articles.abstract: Federal authorities believe that American Media Inc. acted more as a political supporter than as a news organization as it helped Michael D. Cohen suppress embarrassing coverage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal authorities examining the work President Trump’s former lawyer did to squelch embarrassing stories before the 2016 election have come to believe that an important ally in that effort, the tabloid company American Media Inc., at times acted more as a political supporter than as a news organization, according to people briefed on the investigation.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Wild About Tech, China Even Loves Robot Waiters That Can’t Serve
articles.snippet: Some in China are building a future that isn’t quite ready. Still, the exuberance may be a good thing, as useful products find their place and bad ones disappear.
articles.abstract: Some in China are building a future that isn’t quite ready. Still, the exuberance may be a good thing, as useful products find their place and bad ones disappear.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The mind-reading headsets won’t read minds. The fire-detecting machine has been declared a safety hazard. The robot waiter can’t be trusted with the soup.

articles.headline: Their Father Was a Refugee in India. Now They’ve Teamed Up With the Trumps.
articles.snippet: The Trump Organization has struck just one new hotel deal since the president took office. It’s with two brothers doing business in rural Mississippi.
articles.abstract: The Trump Organization has struck just one new hotel deal since the president took office. It’s with two brothers doing business in rural Mississippi.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND, Miss. — Dinesh Chawla has long run his family’s hotel business from a high-top table at a Hampton Inn on the edge of this out-of-the-way Mississippi Delta town. It used to be the kind of work that usually involved friends and neighbors.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Accused of Rape and Torture, Exiled Afghan Vice President Returns
articles.snippet: In a deal with the government, Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum was allowed to come home. Moments after he left the airport, a suicide bomber detonated explosives, killing 20 and wounding 90 others.
articles.abstract: In a deal with the government, Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum was allowed to come home. Moments after he left the airport, a suicide bomber detonated explosives, killing 20 and wounding 90 others.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — After more than a year in exile, Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum returned to his native Afghanistan on Sunday facing criminal charges of rape and kidnapping, as well as accusations of brutality, human rights abuses and killing his first wife.

articles.headline: Decade After Crisis, a $600 Trillion Market Remains Murky to Regulators
articles.snippet: A legal loophole allows major banks to avoid telling American authorities about certain trading in financial instruments known as derivatives.
articles.abstract: A legal loophole allows major banks to avoid telling American authorities about certain trading in financial instruments known as derivatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the maze of subsidiaries that make up Goldman Sachs Group, two in London have nearly identical names: Goldman Sachs International and Goldman Sachs International Bank.

articles.headline: Portugal Dared to Cast Aside Austerity. It’s Having a Major Revival.
articles.snippet: At a time of mounting uncertainty in Europe, the country has defied critics who insisted on austerity as the answer to the Continent’s economic and financial crisis.
articles.abstract: At a time of mounting uncertainty in Europe, the country has defied critics who insisted on austerity as the answer to the Continent’s economic and financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: LISBON — Ramón Rivera had barely gotten his olive oil business started in the sun-swept Alentejo region of Portugal when Europe’s debt crisis struck. The economy crumbled, wages were cut, and unemployment doubled. The government in Lisbon had to accept a humiliating international bailout.

articles.headline: Fiat Chrysler Loses Sergio Marchionne With Bumpy Road Ahead
articles.snippet: The carmaker already faced difficulties, including a reliance on the Jeep and Ram divisions and a limited presence in China, before it was forced to replace its chief executive, Sergio Marchionne.
articles.abstract: The carmaker already faced difficulties, including a reliance on the Jeep and Ram divisions and a limited presence in China, before it was forced to replace its chief executive, Sergio Marchionne.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles was facing an uncertain future even before the man who led its unlikely turnaround became gravely ill.

articles.headline: Israel Picks Identity Over Democracy. More Nations May Follow.
articles.snippet: Israelis are less alone than they once were in questioning the half-century-old consensus that democracy should always prevail over national identity.
articles.abstract: Israelis are less alone than they once were in questioning the half-century-old consensus that democracy should always prevail over national identity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amid a moment of national euphoria, Israel’s founding prime minister, David Ben-Gurion, emerged from retirement in July 1967 to warn Israelis they had sown the seeds of self-destruction.

articles.headline: How a Trump Decision Revealed a G.O.P. Memo’s Shaky Foundation
articles.snippet: Documents released over the weekend plainly demonstrated that key elements of Republicans’ claims about the F.B.I.’s surveillance of Carter Page were misleading or false.
articles.abstract: Documents released over the weekend plainly demonstrated that key elements of Republicans’ claims about the F.B.I.’s surveillance of Carter Page were misleading or false.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump declassified a memo by House Republicans in February that portrayed the surveillance of a former campaign adviser as scandalous, his motivation was clear: to give congressional allies and conservative commentators another avenue to paint the Justice Department’s investigation into Russian election interference as tainted from the start.

articles.headline: 4 Themes to Follow as Corporate America Reports a Surge in Profits
articles.snippet: A growing trade conflict and rising interest rates, wages, commodity prices and other costs that are clouding the economic outlook.
articles.abstract: A growing trade conflict and rising interest rates, wages, commodity prices and other costs that are clouding the economic outlook.
articles.lead_paragraph: Earnings season is upon us once again, and analysts expect the strong economy and the Trump administration’s tax cuts to lead to another batch of knockout quarterly profits.

articles.headline: How a Small Bank Became a Go-To Lender to the Trump Family
articles.snippet: Signature Bank’s close ties to the Trump and Kushner families have led to government scrutiny. New York regulators have opened an investigation.
articles.abstract: Signature Bank’s close ties to the Trump and Kushner families have led to government scrutiny. New York regulators have opened an investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Michael D. Cohen needed $17 million to buy a Manhattan apartment building in 2015, he went to Signature Bank.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and Jesse Drucker

articles.headline: Daily News Newsroom Cut in Half by Tronc as Top Editor Is Ousted
articles.snippet: The Chicago-based media company bought the brawny New York tabloid less than a year ago. On Monday, it announced major cutbacks.
articles.abstract: The Chicago-based media company bought the brawny New York tabloid less than a year ago. On Monday, it announced major cutbacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The meeting lasted less than a minute. By the time it was over, reporters and editors at The Daily News, the brawny New York tabloid that was once the largest-circulation paper in the country, learned that the newsroom staff would be cut in half and that its editor in chief was out of a job.
